chunks.content: Ὅτι μὲν οὖν ἐκ θερμοῦ καὶ ψυχροῦ καὶ ξηροῦ καὶ ὑγροῦ τὰ μὲν ζώων σώματα κέκραται, καὶ ὡς οὐκ ἴση πάντων ἐστὶν ἐν τῇ κράσει μοῖρα, παλαιοῖς ἀνδράσιν ἱκανῶς ἀποδέδεικται, φιλοσόφων τε καὶ ἰατρῶν τοῖς ἀρίστοις· εἴρηται δὲ καὶ πρὸς ἡμῶν ὑπὲρ αὐτῶν τὰ εἰκότα δι’ ἑτέρου γράμματος, ἐν ᾧ περὶ τῶν καθ’ Ἱπποκράτην στοιχείων ἐσκοπούμεθα. νυνὶ δὲ, ὅπερ ἐστὶν ἐφεξῆς ἐκείνῳ, τῶν κράσεων ἁπάσας ἐξευρεῖν τὰς διαφορὰς, ὁπόσαι τέ εἰσι καὶ ὁποῖαι, κατ’ εἴδη τε καὶ γένη διαιρούμενος, ἐν τῷδε τῷ γράμματι δίειμι, τὴν ἀρχὴν ἀπὸ τῆς τῶν ὀνομάτων ἐξηγήσεως ποιησάμενος. ἐπειδὰν μὲν γὰρ ἐκ θερμοῦ καὶ ψυχροῦ καὶ ξηροῦ καὶ ὑγροῦ κεκρᾶσθαι λέγωσι τὰ σώματα, τῶν ἄκρως τοιούτων ἀκούειν φασὶ χρῆναι, τοῦτ’ ἔστι τῶν στοιχείων αὐτῶν, ἀέρος, καὶ πυρὸς, καὶ ὕδατος, καὶ γῆς. ἐπειδὰν δὲ ζῶον, ἢ φυτὸν, ἢ θερμὸν, ἢ ψυχρὸν, ἢ ξηρὸν, ἢ ὑγρὸν, οὐκέθ’ ὡσαύτως. οὐδὲ γὰρ δύνασθαι ζῶον οὐδὲν οὔτ’ ἄκρως θερμὸν ὑπάρχειν, ὡς πῦρ, οὔτ’ ἄκροις ὑγρὸν, ὡς ὕδωρ· ὡσαύτως δὲ οὐδὲ ψυχρὸν ἢ ξηρὸν ἐσχάτως· ἀλλ’ ἀπὸ τοῦ πλεονεκτοῦντος ἐν τῇ κράσει γίνεσθαι τὰς προσηγορίας, ὑγρὸν μὲν καλούντων ἡμῶν, ἐν ᾧ πλείονος ὑγρότητός ἐστι μοῖρα, ξηρὸν δὲ, ἐν ᾧ ξηρότητος· οὕτω δὲ καὶ θερμὸν μὲν, ἐν ᾧ τὸ θερμὸν τοῦ ψυχροῦ πλεονεκτεῖ, ψυχρὸν δὲ, ἐν ᾧ τὸ ψυχρὸν τοῦ θερμοῦ. αὕτη μὲν τῶν ὀνομάτων χρῆσις.
chunks.claude_translation:
# Translation

That the bodies of living creatures are compounded from hot and cold and dry and moist, and that the share of each in the mixture is not equal in all cases, has been adequately demonstrated by the men of old, by the best of both philosophers and physicians. And we ourselves have also stated the probable views concerning these matters in another work, in which we examined the elements according to Hippocrates. But now, which is the next step after that work, I shall proceed in this present writing to discover all the differences of mixtures [temperaments], both how many they are and of what kind, dividing them according to species and genera, beginning with an explanation of the terms.

For whenever they say that bodies are mixed from hot and cold and dry and moist, they assert that one must understand these in their extreme form, that is, the elements themselves: air, fire, water, and earth. But whenever they speak of an animal, or a plant, as hot, or cold, or dry, or moist, it is no longer in the same way. For no animal can be extremely hot, like fire, nor extremely moist, like water; and likewise neither extremely cold nor extremely dry. Rather, the designations arise from what predominates in the mixture, we calling "moist" that in which there is a greater share of moisture, and "dry" that in which there is a greater share of dryness; and similarly also "hot" that in which the hot predominates over the cold, and "cold" that in which the cold predominates over the hot. This, then, is the usage of the terms.
chunks.gemini_translation:
That the bodies of animals are compounded from the hot, the cold, the dry, and the moist, and that the share of each in the temperament [κράσις] is not equal for all, has been sufficiently demonstrated by men of old, by the best of philosophers and physicians. And what is reasonable concerning these matters has also been stated by us in another treatise, in which we investigated the elements according to Hippocrates. Now, however, in this present work, I shall treat the subject that follows next in order: to discover all the differences among the temperaments—how many and of what sort they are—dividing them by species and genera, beginning with an explanation of the terms.

For whenever they say that bodies are compounded from the hot, the cold, the dry, and the moist, they mean that one must understand this to refer to these qualities in their absolute form [τῶν ἄκρως τοιούτων], that is, to the elements themselves: air, fire, water, and earth. But when they call an animal or a plant hot, or cold, or dry, or moist, it is no longer in the same sense. For no animal can be hot in the extreme, like fire, nor wet in the extreme, like water; and likewise, it cannot be cold or dry to the utmost degree. Rather, the designations arise from the predominant quality in the temperament, so that we call a thing moist in which the share of moisture is greater, and dry in which the share of dryness is greater. And so too, a thing is called hot in which the hot prevails over the cold, and cold in which the cold prevails over the hot. This, then, is the use of these terms.
chunks.openai_translation:
That the bodies of animals are mixed from the hot, the cold, the dry, and the wet, and that the share of all is not equal in the [krasis: mixture/temperament], has been sufficiently demonstrated by men of old, the foremost among philosophers and physicians. We too have stated the plausible considerations on these matters in another treatise, in which we examined the elements according to Hippocrates. Now, as what follows upon that, I will in this book go through the discovery of all the differences of the tempers—how many they are and of what sort—dividing them by species and genera, beginning from an explanation of the terms.

For whenever people say that bodies are mixed from the hot and the cold and the dry and the wet, they say one ought to understand things that are such in the extreme—that is, the elements themselves: air, fire, water, and earth. But when it is a matter of an animal or a plant, or of “hot” or “cold” or “dry” or “wet,” not so in the same way. For no animal can be altogether hot like fire, nor altogether wet like water; and likewise neither utterly cold nor utterly dry. Rather, the appellations arise from that which predominates in the [krasis]: we call “wet” that in which there is a greater portion of moisture, and “dry” that in which there is [a greater portion] of dryness; and so too “hot” is that in which the hot prevails over the cold, and “cold” that in which the cold prevails over the hot. Such, then, is the usage of the names.

chunks.content: Ὥρα δ’ ἂν εἴη λέγειν ἤδη καὶ περὶ τῶν κράσεων αὐτῶν ἡ μὲν δὴ πλείστη δόξα τῶν ἐπιφανεστάτων ἰατρῶν τε καὶ φιλοσόφων, ὑγρὰν εἶναι καὶ θερμὴν κρᾶσιν, ἑτέραν τῆς ὑγρᾶς καὶ ψυχρᾶς, καὶ τρίτην ἐπὶ ταύταις τὴν ξηρὰν καὶ ψυχρὰν, ἑτέραν τῆς ξηρᾶς τε ἅμα καὶ θερμῆς ἔνιοι δ’ ἐξ αὐτῶν ὑγρὰν μέν τινα καὶ ψυχρὰν ἅμα κρᾶσιν ὑπάρχειν φασὶ, θερμὴν ἅμα καὶ ξηρὰν ἑτέραν· οὐ μὴν οὔτε τὴν ὑγρὰν ἅμα καὶ θερμὴν, οὔτε τὴν ψυχρὰν ἅμα καὶ ξηράν οὐ γὰρ ἐγχωρεῖν οὔθ’ ὑγρότητα πλεονεκτούσῃ θερμότητι συνδραμεῖν, οὔτε ξηρότητα ψυχρότητι δαπανᾶσθαι μὲν γὰρ ὑπὸ τοῦ θερμοῦ κρατοῦντος τὴν ὑγρότητα, καὶ οὕτως θερμὸν ἅμα καὶ ξηρὸν γίνεσθαι τὸ σῶμα, μένειν δὲ ἄπεπτόν τε καὶ ἀκατέργαστον, ἐν οἶς ἂν σώμασιν ἀῤῥωστῇ τὸ θερμὸν, ὥστ’ ἀναγκαῖον εἶναι, θερμότητος μὲν ἐπικρατούσης, ἕπεσθαι ξηρότητα, ψυχρότητος δὲ πλεονεκτούσης, ἀκολουθεῖν ὑγρότητα οὗτοι μὲν οὖν κατὰ τάδε πεπείκασι σφᾶς αὐτοὺς, ὡς δύο εἰσὶ πᾶσαι τῶν κράσεων αἱ διαφοραί ὅσοι δὲ τέτταρας εἶναι νομίζουσι, διχῶς τούτοις ἀντιλέγουσιν· ἔνιοι μὲν εὐθὺς τὸ πρῶτον ἀξίωμα μὴ συγχωροῦντες, ὡς ἐξικμάζεσθαι τὴν ὑγρότητα πρὸς τοῦ θερμοῦ κρατοῦντος ἀναγκαῖόν ἐστιν· ἔνιοι δὲ τοῦτο μὲν συγχωροῦσιν, ἀμφισβητοῦσι δὲ ἑτέρως οἱ μὲν δὴ πρῶτοι τοῦ θερμοῦ μὲν ἔργον εἶναί φασι τὸ θερμαίνειν, ὥσπερ καὶ τοῦ ψυχροῦ τὸ ψύχειν, τοῦ ξηροῦ δ’ αὖ τὸ ξηραίνειν, ὥσπερ καὶ τοῦ ὑγροῦ τὸ ὑγραίνειν
chunks.claude_translation:
# Translation

It would be time now to speak also about the mixtures [temperaments] themselves. The prevailing opinion of the most distinguished physicians and philosophers is that there is a moist and hot mixture, another that is moist and cold, and a third in addition to these that is dry and cold, and another that is both dry and hot. But some of them say that there exists a certain mixture that is both moist and cold, and another that is both hot and dry; however, neither one that is both moist and hot, nor one that is both cold and dry. For it is not possible either for moisture to accompany predominant heat, or for dryness to accompany coldness. For moisture is consumed by prevailing heat, and thus the body becomes both hot and dry; but in those bodies in which heat is weak, it remains undigested and unprocessed, so that it is necessary that when heat predominates, dryness follows, and when coldness prevails, moisture follows. These men, then, have persuaded themselves on these grounds that there are in all two differences of mixtures. But those who believe there are four oppose them in two ways: some immediately do not grant the first premise, that it is necessary for moisture to be dried out by prevailing heat; but others grant this, yet dispute it in another way. The first group say that the function of heat is to heat, just as that of cold is to cool, and again that of dryness is to dry, just as that of moisture is to moisten.
chunks.gemini_translation:
It would now be time to speak also about the temperaments [kraseis] themselves. The most widespread opinion, then, of the most distinguished physicians and philosophers, is that there is a wet and hot temperament, another that is wet and cold, a third in addition to these that is dry and cold, and another that is at once dry and hot.

Some of them, however, say that a certain temperament that is at once wet and cold exists, and another that is at once hot and dry; but not, however, the one that is at once wet and hot, nor the one that is at once cold and dry. For it is not possible either for wetness to concur with a prevailing heat, or for dryness with coldness. For wetness is consumed by a dominant heat, and thus the body becomes at once hot and dry, while it [wetness] remains undigested [apepton] and unworked in whatever bodies the heat is weak, so that it is necessary, when heat is predominant, for dryness to follow, and when coldness prevails, for wetness to ensue. These men, then, have persuaded themselves on these grounds that all the different types of temperaments are two.

But those who believe there are four argue against them in two ways: some, by not conceding the very first axiom—namely, that it is necessary for the wetness to be dried out by the dominant heat; while others concede this point, but dispute it in another way. The first group, then, says that the function of the hot is to heat, just as that of the cold is to cool, and in turn that of the dry is to dry, just as that of the wet is to moisten.
chunks.openai_translation: It would now be time to speak also about their mixtures [kraseis: mixtures/temperaments]. The most prevalent opinion among the most eminent physicians and philosophers is that there is a moist and hot mixture, another that is moist and cold, and, in addition to these, a third that is dry and cold, and another that is at once dry and hot. Some of them, however, say that there exists a certain mixture that is at once moist and cold, and another that is hot and dry, but not one that is at once moist and hot, nor one that is at once cold and dry. For it is not possible for moisture to go together with prevailing heat, nor for dryness with cold: for the moisture is expended by the heat that is dominant, and thus the body becomes at once hot and dry, yet remains undigested and unworked [apep-ton and akatergaston: unconcocted/unprocessed], in those bodies in which the heat is in a diseased condition; so that it is necessary that, when heat prevails, dryness follows, and when cold has the advantage, moisture accompanies. These people have accordingly persuaded themselves on these grounds that all the differences of mixtures are two. Those, however, who think there are four oppose them in two ways: some do not grant the very first premise—that it is necessary for the moisture to be dried out by the prevailing heat; others grant this, but dispute otherwise. The first say that it is the function of the hot to heat, just as of the cold to cool, and again of the dry to dry, and of the moist to moisten.

chunks.content: καὶ διὰ τοῦτο, ὅσα μὲν σώματα θερμὰ τὴν φύσιν ἐστὶν ἅμα καὶ ξηρὰ, καθάπερ τὸ πῦρ, ᾗ μὲν θερμὰ, θερμαίνει, ᾗ δὲ ξηρὰ, ξηραίνει ὅσα δ’ ὑγρὰ καὶ θερμὰ, καθάπερ ὕδωρ θερμὸν, ὑγραίνειν ταῦτα καὶ θερμαίνειν πέφυκεν ἀεὶ, ἓν ἑκατέρας κᾀνταῦθα ποιότητος ἔργον ἐχούσης ἀχώριστον οὐκ οὖν συγχωροῦσιν, εἴ τι θερμαῖνόν ἐστιν, εὐθὺς τοῦτο καὶ ξηραίνειν· ἀλλ’ εἰ μὲν ὑγρότης προσείη τῇ θερμότητι, θερμαίνειν ἅμα καὶ ὑγραίνειν, ὥσπερ τὰ λουτρὰ τῶν γλυκέων ὑδάτων· εἰ δ’, ὥσπερ θερμὸν, οὕτω καὶ ξηρὸν εἴη, καθάπερ τὸ πῦρ, οὐ θερμαίνειν μόνον, ἀλλὰ καὶ ξηραίνειν εὐθὺς, οὐκ ἐκ τῆς θερμότητος τοῦτο λαβὸν, ἀλλ’ ἐκ τῆς συνούσης αὐτῇ ξηρότητος ὑπομιμνήσκουσι δ’ ἐνταῦθα τῶν ἐν ἡλίῳ θερινῷ διατριψάντων ἐπιπλέον, εἶθ’, ὡς εἰκὸς, αὐανθέντων, ὅλον τε τὸ σῶμα καὶ ξηρὸν καὶ αὐχμηρὸν ἐχόντων, καὶ διψώντων οὐκ ἀνεκτῶς ἴασιν γὰρ αὐτοῖς εἶναί φασιν ἑτοίμην τε καὶ ῥᾴστην, οὐκ εἰ πίοιεν μόνον, ἀλλὰ εἰ καὶ λούσαιντο θερμοῖς ὕδασι καὶ γλυκέσιν, ὡς τῆς ὑγρότητος, εἴτε μετὰ ψυχρότητος, εἴτε μετὰ θερμότητος εἴη, τὸ ἑαυτῆς δρᾷν δυναμένης, ὑγραίνειν γὰρ τὰ πλησιάζοντα κατὰ δὲ τὸν αὐτὸν λόγον φασὶ καὶ τὴν ξηρότητα ξηραίνειν ἀεί τὸν γοῦν βοῤῥᾶν, ξηρὸν καὶ ψυχρὸν ἄνεμον τυγχάνοντα, ξηραίνειν ἅπαντα καὶ ψύχειν καὶ τοῦτ’ εἶναι τὸ πρὸς Ὁμήρου λεγόμενον, Ὡς δ’ ὅτ’ ὀπωρινὸς βορέης νεοαρδέ’ ἀλωὴν Αἶψα ξηραίνει
chunks.claude_translation:
# Translation of Text 2.2:

And because of this, those bodies which are hot in nature and at the same time dry, such as fire, insofar as they are hot, heat, and insofar as they are dry, dry; but those which are moist and hot, such as hot water, are naturally suited to moisten and heat always, each quality in these cases too having one inseparable function. Therefore they do not concede that if something heats, it immediately also dries; but if moisture is present along with the heat, it heats and moistens at the same time, just as baths of fresh water do; but if, just as it is hot, so too it is dry, like fire, it not only heats but also immediately dries, deriving this not from the heat but from the dryness that accompanies it. And here they remind us of those who have spent excessive time in the summer sun, and then, as is natural, have become parched, having their whole body both dry and withered, and suffering unbearably from thirst; for they say that the cure for them is ready and very easy, not only if they drink, but also if they bathe in hot and fresh waters, on the grounds that moisture, whether it be with coldness or with heat, is able to do its own work, namely to moisten what comes near it. And by the same reasoning they say that dryness also always dries. At any rate, the north wind [Boreas], being a dry and cold wind, dries and cools everything. And this is what is said by Homer: "As when the autumn north wind quickly dries a newly watered threshing floor."
chunks.gemini_translation:
And for this reason, all bodies that are by nature hot and at the same time dry, such as fire, heat by virtue of being hot and dry by virtue of being dry. But all those that are moist and hot, such as hot water, are by nature always able to moisten and to heat, with each quality in this case too having its own inseparable function. Therefore, they do not concede that if something heats, it must immediately also dry. Rather, if moisture is present with the heat, as in the case of baths of fresh [lit. sweet] waters, it heats and moistens at the same time. But if a thing should be dry just as it is hot, like fire, it not only heats but also immediately dries, deriving this latter effect not from its heat, but from the dryness that accompanies it.

In this regard, they remind us of those who have spent too much time in the summer sun and then, as is to be expected, have become withered, their whole body growing dry and parched, and suffering from unbearable thirst. For they say that a ready and very easy cure is available to them, not only if they drink, but also if they bathe in hot and fresh waters, on the grounds that moisture, whether it is combined with coldness or with heat, is able to perform its own function—for it moistens things that are near it. And following the same line of reasoning, they say that dryness, too, always dries. The north wind, for instance, being a dry and cold wind, dries and cools everything. And this, they say, is what is meant by Homer’s line: "As when the autumnal north wind swiftly dries a newly-watered threshing-floor..."
chunks.openai_translation: And for this reason, all bodies that are by nature both hot and dry, like fire, inasmuch as they are hot, heat, and inasmuch as they are dry, dry; whereas those that are moist and hot, like hot water, are by nature always to moisten and to heat, each of the two qualities [quality] here having an inseparable effect of its own. They therefore do not allow that, if something heats, it immediately also dries; rather, if moisture is added to heat, it both heats and moistens at the same time, as do baths of fresh [i.e., not salty] water; but if, being hot, it is also dry, like fire, it not only heats but at once dries as well—this resulting not from the heat, but from the dryness that accompanies it. They remind us here of those who have lingered overlong in the summer sun and then, as is to be expected, have become parched, having their whole body dry and arid and suffering intolerable thirst. For they say there is for them a ready and easiest remedy, not only if they drink, but even if they bathe in warm and fresh [i.e., not salty] waters, since moisture—whether it be with cold or with heat—is able to accomplish its own proper work; for it moistens whatever comes near. And by the same reasoning they say that dryness always dries: Boreas, at any rate—being a dry and cold wind—dries everything and cools; and that this is what is said with reference to Homer: “As when the autumnal Boreas swiftly dries a newly watered orchard.”

chunks.content: Κατὰ δὲ τὸν αὐτὸν τρόπον καὶ τὸν τοῦ μήκωνος ὀπὸν καὶ ἄλλα μυρία φάρμακα ξηραίνειν ἅμα καὶ ψύχειν ὥστ’ οὐκ ἀναγκαῖον, οὔτ’ εἴ τι ψυχρὸν, εὐθὺς τοῦτο καὶ ὑγρὸν ὑπάρχειν, οὔτ’, εἴ τι θερμὸν, εὐθὺς καὶ ξηρόν· οὔκουν οὐδὲ τὴν θερμὴν κρᾶσιν ἐξ ἀνάγκης εἶναι καὶ ξηρὰν, ἀλλὰ δύνασθαί ποτε τὸ μὲν θερμὸν τοῦ ψυχροῦ πλεονεκτεῖν ἐν τῇ κράσει τοῦ ζώου, τὸ δ’ ὑγρὸν τοῦ ξηροῦ καὶ γὰρ δὴ καὶ τὴν γένεσιν, καὶ τὴν ἀλλοίωσιν, καὶ τὴν μεταβολὴν ἐκ τῶν ἐναντίων εἰς τὰ ἐναντία γίνεσθαι τίς γὰρ οὖν εἰπὼν, ὅτι τὸ λευκὸν ἠλλοιώθη τε καὶ μετέβαλεν, ἐγένετο γὰρ θερμὸν, οὐκ ἂν εἴη καταγέλαστος ἐπιζητεῖ γὰρ ὁ λόγος, οὐ τὴν κατὰ ψυχρὸν καὶ θερμὸν ἀντίθεσιν, ἀλλὰ τὴν κατὰ τὸ χρῶμα μεταβολήν· μεταβάλλει γὰρ τὸ μὲν λευκὸν εἰς τὸ μέλαν, ὥσπερ καὶ τὸ μέλαν εἰς τὸ λευκὸν, καὶ τὸ θερμὸν αὖ εἰς τὸ ψυχρὸν, ὥσπερ καὶ τὸ ψυχρὸν εἰς τὸ θερμόν οὕτω δὲ καὶ τὸ μὲν ὑγρὸν εἰς τὸ ξηρὸν, τὸ δ’ αὖ ξηρὸν εἰς τὸ ὑγρόν εἰ γὰρ δὴ φάσκει τις ἠλλοιῶσθαι τὸ σῶμα τῷ τέως ὑγρὸν ὑπάρχον εἶναι νῦν λευκὸν, ἢ τῷ τέως ξηρὸν ὂν τὸ νῦν φαίνεσθαι μέλαν, οὐκ ἂν ὑγιαίνειν δόξειεν εἰ δέ γε τὸ τέως ὑγρὸν τὸ νῦν ξηρὸν φαίη γενέσθαι, ἢ τὸ πρότερον ὑπάρχον μέλαν νῦν εἶναι λευκὸν, ἢ ἐκ θερμοῦ ψυχρὸν, ἢ ἐκ ψυχροῦ θερμὸν γεγονέναι, σωφρονεῖν ἂν δόξειεν ὁ τοιοῦτος, καὶ λέγειν τὰ εἰκότα
chunks.claude_translation:
# Translation of Text 2.3:

And in the same manner, poppy juice and countless other drugs both dry and cool at the same time, so that it is not necessary that if something is cold, it should immediately also be moist, nor if something is hot, should it immediately also be dry. Therefore, neither is it necessary that a hot mixture should also be dry, but it is possible sometimes for the hot to predominate over the cold in the mixture of a living creature, and the moist over the dry. For indeed, both generation and alteration and change occur from opposites to opposites. For who, having said that the white thing has been altered and changed—for it has become hot—would not be ridiculous? For the argument seeks not the opposition according to cold and hot, but the change according to color. For the white changes into the black, just as the black also changes into the white, and the hot in turn into the cold, just as the cold also into the hot. And in the same way, the moist changes into the dry, and the dry in turn into the moist. For if someone should claim that a body has been altered because what was formerly moist is now white, or because what was formerly dry now appears black, he would not seem to be in his right mind. But if he should say that what was formerly moist has now become dry, or that what previously was black is now white, or that it has become cold from hot, or hot from cold, such a person would seem to be sensible and to speak reasonably.
chunks.gemini_translation:
And in the same way, the juice of the poppy and countless other drugs both dry and cool at the same time, so that it is not necessary for something cold to be immediately also moist, nor for something hot to be immediately also dry. Therefore, a hot temperament is not necessarily also a dry one, but it is possible for the hot to predominate over the cold in the temperament [krasis] of a living being, while the moist predominates over the dry.

For indeed, generation, alteration, and change all occur from opposites to their opposites. For who, then, by saying that "the white thing was altered and changed, for it became hot," would not be ridiculous? For the argument requires not the opposition between cold and hot, but the change in respect to color. For white changes into black, just as black changes into white, and hot in turn into cold, just as cold into hot; and so also the moist into the dry, and the dry in turn into the moist.

For if someone were to assert that a body has been altered in that, having been moist before, it is now white, or in that, being dry before, it now appears black, he would not seem to be of sound mind. But if he were to say that what was formerly moist has now become dry, or that what was previously black is now white, or has become cold from hot, or hot from cold, such a person would seem to be sensible and to be speaking plausibly.
chunks.openai_translation: And in the same way the juice of the poppy [opium] and countless other drugs both dry and cool at once, so that it is not necessary that, if something is cold, it is straightway also moist, nor, if something is hot, straightway also dry. Accordingly, a hot krasis [mixture/temperament] is not of necessity also dry, but it can happen that the hot has the advantage over the cold in the mixture of the living creature, while the moist has the advantage over the dry. For indeed generation, alteration, and change come to be from contraries into contraries. For who would not be laughable if he said that the white had been altered and had changed—“for it became hot”? For the account is concerned not with the opposition according to cold and hot, but with the change according to color. For white changes into black, just as black into white, and the hot in turn into the cold, just as the cold into the hot; and so too the moist into the dry, and again the dry into the moist. For if someone claims that the body has been altered in this respect, that what was formerly moist is now white, or that what was formerly dry now appears black, he would not seem to be sensible; but if he were to say that what was formerly moist has now become dry, or that what previously existed as black is now white, or that from hot it has become cold, or from cold hot, such a person would seem to be in his senses and to be saying what is reasonable.

chunks.content: τὸ γὰρ μεταβάλλον, ᾗ μεταβάλλει, ταύτῃ μεταχωρεῖν δεῖ πρὸς τοὐναντίον ἐγένετο γοῦν ἢ γίγνεται μουσικὸς ὅδε, φαμὲν, ἐξ οὐ μουσικοῦ δηλονότι, καὶ γραμματικὸς ἐξ οὐ γραμματικοῦ, καὶ ῥητορικὸς ἐξ οὐ ῥητορικοῦ· τὸ δ’ ἐκ μουσικοῦ γραμματικὸν, ἢ ἐκ γραμματικοῦ μουσικὸν, ἢ ἐξ ἄλλου τινὸς τῶν ἑτερογενῶν γίνεσθαί τι λέγειν ἄτοπον ἐγχωρεῖ γὰρ τὸν τέως γραμματικὸν νῦν μουσικὸν γεγονέναι, προσκτησάμενον τῇ γραμματικῇ τὴν μουσικὴν, οὐκ ἀποβαλόντα τὴν γραμματικήν καὶ μὴν εἰ προσεκτήσατό τι, μένοντος τοῦ προτέρου, παντί που δῆλον, ὡς οὐκ ἠλλοιώθη κατὰ τὸ μένον ὥστ’ οὐκ ἐκ γραμματικοῦ μουσικὸς ἐγένετο· καὶ γὰρ καὶ νῦν ἔτι γραμματικός ἐστιν· ἀλλ’ ἐξ ἀμούσου μουσικός· οὐ γὰρ ἔτ’ ἐγχωρεῖ μένειν αὐτὸν ἄμουσον, μουσικόν γε ἤδη γεγονότα πασῶν γοῦν τῶν μεταβολῶν ὑπὸ τῶν ἐναντίων τε κᾀκ τῶν ἐναντίων εἰς τὰ ἐναντία γιγνομένων, δηλονότι καὶ τὸ ὑγρὸν, εἰ μεταβάλλει ποτὲ, καθ’ ὅσον ὑγρὸν, αὐτό τε ξηρανθήσεται καὶ τὸ ξηραῖνον αὐτὸ ξηρὸν λεχθήσεται μὴ τοίνυν λεγόντων, φασὶν, ὡς θερμὴν ἅμα καὶ ὑγρὰν κρᾶσιν οὐκ ἐγχωρεῖ γενέσθαι θερμὴν μὲν γὰρ ἅμα καὶ ψυχρὰν εἶναι τὴν αὐτὴν, ἢ ὑγρὰν ἅμα καὶ ξηρὰν οὐκ ἐγχωρεῖ· συνυπάρχειν γὰρ ἀλλήλαις οὐχ οἷόν τε καθ’ ἓν καὶ ταὐτὸ σῶμα τὰς ἐναντίας ποιότητας· ἅμα δ’ ὑγρόν τι καὶ θερμὸν, καὶ ψυχρὸν ἅμα καὶ ξηρὸν εἶναι δυνατὸν, ὡς ὅ τε λόγος ἀπέδειξε καὶ τὰ σμικρῷ πρόσθεν εἰρημένα παραδείγματα
chunks.claude_translation:
# Translation of Text 2.4:

For that which changes, insofar as it changes, must in that respect move toward the opposite. At any rate, this person became or becomes musical, we say, from being non-musical obviously, and literate from being non-literate, and rhetorical from being non-rhetorical. But to say that something becomes literate from being musical, or musical from being literate, or from some other heterogeneous quality is absurd. For it is possible that someone who was formerly literate has now become musical, having acquired music in addition to literacy, not having lost literacy. And yet if he has acquired something in addition while the former quality remains, it is surely clear to everyone that he has not been altered with respect to what remains. So he did not become musical from being literate; for indeed even now he is still literate. Rather, he became musical from being non-musical; for it is no longer possible for him to remain non-musical, since he has already become musical. Therefore, since all changes occur by contraries and from contraries into contraries, it is clear that the moist too, if it ever changes, insofar as it is moist, will itself be dried and that which dries it will be called dry. Therefore, they say, let them not claim that it is impossible for a mixture to be both hot and moist at the same time. For it is impossible for the same thing to be both hot and cold at the same time, or both moist and dry at the same time; for it is not possible for contrary qualities to coexist in one and the same body. But it is possible for something to be both moist and hot at the same time, and both cold and dry at the same time, as both the argument has demonstrated and the examples stated a little earlier.
chunks.gemini_translation:
For that which changes, insofar as it changes, must in that respect pass over to its contrary. For example, this person became or is becoming musical, we say, from being non-musical, clearly; and literate from non-literate, and rhetorical from non-rhetorical. But to say that something becomes literate from being musical, or musical from being literate, or that anything comes to be from some other thing of a different kind, is absurd.

For it is possible for one who was formerly literate to have now become musical by having acquired musicality in addition to his literacy, not by having cast off his literacy. And indeed, if he acquired something while the former thing remained, it is surely clear to everyone that he was not altered with respect to that which remained. Therefore, he did not become musical *from* being literate—for in fact he is still literate even now—but rather musical *from* being unmusical; for it is no longer possible for him to remain unmusical, having now become musical.

Since, at any rate, all changes are brought about by contraries and proceed from contraries to contraries, it is clear that the moist, too, if it ever changes *insofar as it is moist*, will both be dried itself, and that which dries it will be called dry.

Therefore, let them not say, they claim, that a temperament [Greek: *krasis*, mixture or constitution] that is at once hot and moist cannot come to be. For it is not possible for the same thing to be at once hot and cold, or at once moist and dry; for it is not possible for contrary qualities to coexist with one another in one and the same body. But it is possible for something to be at once moist and hot, and at once cold and dry, as both the argument has shown and the examples stated a little earlier.
chunks.openai_translation:
For that which undergoes change, in so far as it changes, must in that respect pass over to the opposite. For example, we say that this man became, or becomes, musical from being unmusical, plainly, and a grammarian from being not a grammarian, and a rhetorician from being not a rhetorician. But to say that something becomes a grammarian from being a musician, or a musician from being a grammarian, or from some other of the states that are different in kind [heterogeneous], is absurd. For it is possible that one who was formerly a grammarian has now become a musician, having acquired music in addition to grammar, not having cast off grammar. And indeed, if he has acquired something while the former thing remains, it is plain to everyone that he has not been altered with respect to what remains; so he did not become musical from being a grammarian—for even now he is still a grammarian—but from being unmusical. For it is no longer admissible that he remain unmusical, once he has already become musical. In general, all changes both are produced by contraries and proceed from contraries into contraries [contraries = hot/cold, wet/dry]. Clearly, then, the wet, if it ever changes, in so far as it is wet, will itself be dried, and that which dries it will be called dry.

Let them not, then, say—as they allege—that it is not possible for a mixture [krasis] that is at once hot and wet to come to be. For it is not possible for the same thing to be at once hot and cold, or at once wet and dry; for contrary qualities cannot coexist with each other in one and the same body. But it is possible for something to be at once wet and hot, and at once cold and dry, as both the argument has demonstrated and the examples mentioned a little earlier.

chunks.content: τοιοῦτος μὲν οὖν ὁ τῶν προτέρων λόγος ὁ δὲ τῶν δευτέρων οὐδὲν ἄτοπον εἶναί φησιν, ὑποκειμένου τοῦ θερμοῦ δραστικωτάτου τῶν τεττάρων, ὡς μὴ μόνον εἰς τὸ ψυχρὸν, ἀλλὰ καὶ εἰς τὸ ὑγρὸν ἐνεργεῖν, εἶναι κρᾶσιν ὑγρὰν καὶ θερμὴν, ὅταν ἐς ταὐτὸ ἅμα συνέλθῃ πλῆθος ὑγρότητός τε καὶ θερμότητος εὐθὺς ἐν τῇ πρώτῃ γενέσει τοῦ ζώου ὁ δὲ λόγος ἐκείνων οὐχ, ὡς οὐκ ἄν ποτε γένοιτο καθ’ ἓν καὶ ταὐτὸ σῶμα τὸ μὲν ὑγρὸν τοῦ ξηροῦ πλέον, τὸ δὲ θερμὸν τοῦ ψυχροῦ, δείκνυσιν, ἀλλ’ ὡς οὐκ ἂν διαμείναι τοιοῦτο ἄχρι παντός· ἀεὶ γὰρ ἐξικμαζόμενον ὑπὸ τοῦ θερμοῦ τὸ ὑγρὸν ἐν τῷ χρόνῳ ξηρὸν ἀποδείξει τὸ σῶμα· καὶ οὕτως οὐκ ἂν ἔτι θερμὸν καὶ ὑγρὸν, ἀλλὰ θερμὸν εἴη καὶ ξηρόν· αὐτὸ δ’ οὖν πάλιν τοῦτο, τὸ θερμὸν καὶ ξηρὸν, ἐπὶ προήκοντι τῷ χρόνῳ ξηρὸν ἔσται καὶ ψυχρόν ἐπειδὰν γὰρ ἐκβοσκήσηται τὴν ἰκμάδα πᾶσαν αὐτοῦ τὸ θερμὸν, ἄρχεται τοὐντεῦθεν ἤδη, φασὶ, καὶ αὐτὸ μαραίνεσθαι, μηκέτ’ εὐποροῦν τροφῆς, ὅθεν ἐξήπτετο θαυμαστὸν οὖν οὐδὲν εἶναι νομίζουσι, καὶ κατ’ ἀρχὰς μὲν εὐθὺς ἐν τῇ πρώτῃ γενέσει τοῦ ζώου συνδραμεῖν εἰς ταὐτὸ ἢ τὸ ὑγρὸν τοῦ ξηροῦ πλέον, ἢ τὸ θερμὸν τοῦ ψυχροῦ δυνατὸν δὲ κᾀν τῷ χρόνῳ προϊόντι γίνεσθαι τὴν τέως θερμὴν καὶ ὑγρὰν κρᾶσιν αὖθις θερμὴν καὶ ξηρὰν, ὥσπερ γε καὶ αὖθις πάλιν τὴν ξηρὰν καὶ θερμὴν, ἀποσβεννυμένου τοῦ θερμοῦ, ψυχρὰν καὶ ξηρὰν ἀποτελεσθῆναι ὅτι μὲν οὖν ἐγχωρεῖ καὶ θερμὴν ἅμα καὶ ὑγρὰν εἶναί τινα, καὶ ψυχρὰν καὶ ξηρὰν ἑτέραν τῆσδε κρᾶσιν, ἐκ τούτων ἀποδεικνύουσιν ὅτι δὲ πλείους τῶν τεττάρων διαφορὰς κράσεων ἀδύνατον ὑπάρχειν, ἐκ τῶνδε πειρῶνται διδάσκειν
chunks.claude_translation:
# Translation of Text 2.5

Such then is the argument of the first group. But the argument of the second group says that there is nothing absurd, given that heat is the most active of the four [qualities], so that it acts not only upon the cold but also upon the moist, in there being a mixture that is moist and hot, whenever an abundance of both moisture and heat comes together at the same time right from the first generation of the living creature. But the argument of those others demonstrates not that there could never be in one and the same body the moist exceeding the dry and the hot exceeding the cold, but rather that such a condition could not persist forever. For since the moisture is always being evaporated by the heat, in time it will render the body dry; and thus it would no longer be hot and moist, but would be hot and dry. And then again, this very thing, the hot and dry, as time advances will become dry and cold. For whenever the heat has consumed all its moisture, from that point on, they say, it too begins to wither away, no longer having an abundant supply of nourishment from which it was kindled. Therefore they consider it not at all remarkable both that at the beginning, right from the first generation of the living creature, there should come together at the same time either the moist in excess of the dry or the hot in excess of the cold, and that it is also possible as time progresses for the mixture that was previously hot and moist to become in turn hot and dry, just as again in turn the dry and hot mixture, when the heat is extinguished, becomes cold and dry. That it is possible for there to be both some mixture that is at once hot and moist, and another different from this one that is cold and dry, they demonstrate from these arguments. But that it is impossible for there to be more than four varieties of mixtures, they attempt to teach from the following considerations.
chunks.gemini_translation:
Such, then, is the argument of the first group. But the argument of the second group states that there is nothing absurd, on the assumption that the hot is the most active of the four qualities, in its having an effect not only on the cold but also on the moist, for there to be a temperament [krasis] that is moist and hot, whenever an abundance of both moisture and heat comes together at the same time, right at the first generation of a living creature. The argument of the former group, however, demonstrates not that there could never be in one and the same body more of the moist than the dry and more of the hot than the cold, but that such a state could not persist indefinitely. For the moisture, being constantly dried out by the heat, will in time render the body dry; and thus it would no longer be hot and moist, but would be hot and dry. Then this very state, the hot and dry, will in turn, over an extended period of time, become dry and cold. For when the heat has consumed all of the body's moisture, from that point on, they say, it too begins to wither away, no longer having a ready supply of the nourishment from which it was kindled.

Therefore, they consider it in no way surprising that, at the very beginning, in the first generation of a living creature, either more of the moist than the dry, or more of the hot than the cold, should combine in the same place. And it is possible, as time goes on, for the temperament that was for a time hot and moist to become in turn hot and dry, just as, in turn, the hot and dry temperament, as its heat is extinguished, is rendered cold and dry. From these arguments, therefore, they demonstrate that it is possible for one temperament to be at once hot and moist, and for another to be cold and dry. But that it is impossible for more than four varieties of temperaments to exist, they attempt to show from the following points.
chunks.openai_translation:
Such, then, is the account of the former; but the account of the latter says that there is nothing absurd in this, on the supposition that the hot is the most active of the four, so that it acts not only upon the cold but also upon the moist—that there is a moist and hot mixture [krasis], whenever at once, in the animal’s first coming-to-be, a mass of both moisture and heat converges into one and the same thing.

And their account does not show that it could never occur in one and the same body that the moist is more than the dry while the hot is more than the cold, but rather that such a condition would not remain so forever; for the moist, being continually dried out by the hot, will in time render the body dry, and thus it would no longer be hot and moist, but hot and dry. This very state again, the hot and dry, in due course of time will become dry and cold; for whenever the heat has grazed out [i.e., consumed] all its sap [moisture], from then on, they say, it too begins to wither, no longer well supplied with the nourishment from which it had been kindled.

Accordingly, they think it is nothing surprising if, even at the beginning, right at the animal’s first coming-to-be, either the moist in excess of the dry or the hot in excess of the cold should converge into the same subject; and that, as time advances, it is possible for the mixture that was previously hot and moist to become again hot and dry, just as, in turn, the dry and hot—when the heat is quenched—is brought to completion as cold and dry.

That, then, it is possible for there to be at once some [mixture] that is hot and moist, and another mixture different from this one, cold and dry, they demonstrate from these considerations; but that it is impossible for there to be more than four differences of mixtures, they attempt to teach from the following.

chunks.content: ὑποκειμένων γὰρ, φασὶ, τεττάρων ποιοτήτων, εἰς ἀλλήλας τε τὸ δρᾷν καὶ πάσχειν ἐχουσῶν, θερμότητός τε καὶ ψυχρότητος, καὶ ξηρότητος καὶ ὑγρότητος, ἀντιθέσεις γίνεσθαι δύο, τὴν μὲν ἑτέραν, ἐν ᾗ τὸ θερμὸν ἀντίκειται τῷ ψυχρῷ, τὴν δ’ ἑτέραν, ἐν ᾗ τὸ ξηρὸν τῷ ὑγρῷ, καὶ διὰ τοῦτο τέτταρας ἀποτελεῖσθαι τὰς πάσας συζυγίας ἓξ μὲν γὰρ γίνεσθαι τῶν τεττάρων ἀλλήλαις ἐπιπλεκομένων τὰς συζεύξεις, ἀλλὰ τὰς δύο τούτων ἀδυνάτους ὑπάρχειν οὔτε γὰρ ὑγρὸν ἅμα καὶ ξηρὸν, οὔτε ψυχρὸν ἅμα καὶ θερμὸν δύναται γενέσθαι σῶμα λείπεται γοῦν τέτταρας εἶναι συζυγίας κράσεων, ὑγρὰς μὲν δύο, ξηρὰς δὲ δύο, θερμότητι καὶ ψυχρότητι διῃρημένας ἃ μὲν οὖν οἱ χαριέστατοι τῶν πρὸ ἡμῶν ἰατρῶν τε καὶ φιλοσόφων εἰρήκασι, ταῦτά ἐστιν ἃ δ’ ἐγὼ παραλιπεῖν αὐτοὺς νομίζω, λέγειν ἤδη καιρός.
chunks.claude_translation:
# Translation of Text 2.6:

For they say that, there being four underlying qualities, which have the power both to act upon and be acted upon by one another—namely heat and cold, and dryness and moisture—two oppositions arise: one in which the hot is opposed to the cold, and the other in which the dry is opposed to the moist. And for this reason, four combinations in all are produced. For when the four are interwoven with one another, six couplings arise, but two of these are impossible to exist; for a body can become neither moist and dry at the same time, nor cold and hot at the same time. Therefore, four combinations of mixtures [*kraseis*] remain: two moist and two dry, distinguished by heat and cold. Now these, then, are the things that the most elegant of the physicians and philosophers before us have said. But what I believe they have omitted, it is now time to discuss.
chunks.gemini_translation: For, they say, since there are four underlying qualities which possess the capacity to act and be acted upon towards each other—namely, hotness and coldness, and dryness and wetness—two oppositions arise: the one, in which the hot is opposed to the cold, and the other, in which the dry is opposed to the wet. And for this reason, four total combinations [syzygies] are brought to completion. For although six pairings are formed when the four are interwoven with one another, two of these are impossible; for a body cannot become at the same time wet and dry, nor at the same time cold and hot. It is left, therefore, that there are four combinations of mixtures [kraseis]: two of them wet and two dry, distinguished by hotness and coldness. What the most distinguished of the physicians and philosophers before us have said, then, is this. But what I believe they have omitted, it is now time to state.
chunks.openai_translation: For, they say, since four qualities are posited, which have the capacity to act upon and be acted upon by one another—heat and cold, and dryness and moistness—two oppositions arise, the one in which the hot is opposed to the cold, and the other in which the dry is opposed to the moist; and for this reason the total number of couplings [syzygies] comes to four—for six couplings arise when the four are interwoven with one another, but two of these prove impossible; for a body cannot be at once moist and dry, nor at once cold and hot. Accordingly, there remain four pairings of mixtures [kraseis]: two moist and two dry, distinguished by heat and cold. Such, then, are the things that the most elegant of our predecessors among physicians and philosophers have said; but as for what I think they have left out, it is now time to say it.
